On the Approximation and Smoothed Complexity of
Leontief Market Equilibria

Li-Sha Huang
Department of Computer Science
Tsinghua University
Beijing, China ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Shang-Hua Teng

Boston, Massachusetts, USA Also affiliated with Akamai Technologies Inc. Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA. Partially supported by NSF grants CCR-0311430 and ITR CCR-0325630. Part of this work done while visiting Tsinghua University.
Abstract

We show that the problem of finding an œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ-approximate Nash equilibrium of an n√ónùëõùëõn\times nitalic_n √ó italic_n two-person games can be reduced to the computation of an (œµ/n)2superscriptitalic-œµùëõ2(\epsilon/n)^{2}( italic_œµ / italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-approximate market equilibrium of a Leontief economy. Together with a recent result of Chen, Deng and Teng, this polynomial reduction implies that the Leontief market exchange problem does not have a fully polynomial-time approximation scheme, that is, there is no algorithm that can compute an œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ-approximate market equilibrium in time polynomial in mùëömitalic_m, nùëõnitalic_n, and 1/œµ1italic-œµ1/\epsilon1 / italic_œµ, unless PPAD ‚äÜ\subseteq‚äÜ P, We also extend the analysis of our reduction to show, unless PPAD ‚äÜ\subseteq‚äÜ RP, that the smoothed complexity of the Scarf‚Äôs general fixed-point approximation algorithm (when applying to solve the approximate Leontief market exchange problem) or of any algorithm for computing an approximate market equilibrium of Leontief economies is not polynomial in nùëõnitalic_n and 1/œÉ1ùúé1/\sigma1 / italic_œÉ, under Gaussian or uniform perturbations with magnitude œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ.

The individual objective of each trader is to maximize his or her utility. However, the utilities that these traders can achieve depend on the initial endowments, the individual utilities, and potentially, the (complex) process that they perform their exchanges.

In Walras‚Äô pure view of economics [26], the individual objectives of traders and their initial endowments enable the market to establish a price vector ùê©ùê©\mathbf{p}bold_p of the goods in the market. Then the whole exchange can be conceptually characterized as: the traders sell their endowments ‚Äì to obtain money or budgets ‚Äì and individually optimize their objectives by buying the bundles of goods that maximize their utilities.

In other words, an equilibrium price vector essentially allows each trader to make individual decision without considering others‚Äô utilities nor how they achieve their objectives.

The computation of a market equilibrium is a fundamental problem in modern economics [23] as Walrasian equilibria might provide useful information for the prediction of market trends, in the decision for future investments, and in the development of economic policies. So a central complexity question in Leontief market exchange problem is:

Question 1 (Polynomial Leontief?).

Is the problem of computing an equilibrium of a Leontief economy in P?

So far no polynomial-time algorithm has been found for this problem. In practice, one may be willing to relax the condition of equilibria and considers the computation of approximate market equilibria. For example, Scarf [22] developed a general algorithm for computing approximate fixed points and equilibria. Recently, Deng, Papadimitriou, Safra [8] proposed a notion of an approximate market equilibrium as a price vector that allows each trader to independently and approximately optimize her utilities.

Question 2 (Fully Polynomial Approximate Leontief?).

Can an œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ-approximate equilibrium of a Leontief economy with mùëömitalic_m goods and nùëõnitalic_n traders be computed in time polynomial in mùëömitalic_m, nùëõnitalic_n, and 1/œµ1italic-œµ1/\epsilon1 / italic_œµ?

The combination of two recent results greatly dashed the hope for a positive answer to Question 1. Codenotti, Saberi, Varadarajan, and Ye [5] gave a polynomial-time reduction from two-person games to a special case of the Leontief economy. In a remarkable breakthrough, Chen and Deng [3] subsequently proved that the problem of finding a Nash equilibrium of a two-person game is PPAD-complete333We refer the readers who are not familiar with the complexity class PPAD to the paper by Papadimitriou [21] and also to the subsequent papers on the PPAD-completeness of normal games [6, 2, 7, 3, 4]. This class includes several important search problems such as various discrete fixed-point problems and the problem of finding a Nash equilibrium of rùëüritalic_r-person games for any fixed rùëüritalic_r. .

In this paper, we show that there is no fully polynomial-time approximation scheme for Leontief economies unless PPAD ‚äÜ\subseteq‚äÜ P. Hence it is unlikely that Question 2 has a positive answer. By analyzing the numerical properties of the reduction of Condenotti, Saberi, Varadarajan, and Ye [5], we prove that the problem of finding an œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ-approximate Nash equilibrium of an n√ónùëõùëõn\times nitalic_n √ó italic_n two-person games can be reduced to the computation of an (œµ/n)2superscriptitalic-œµùëõ2(\epsilon/n)^{2}( italic_œµ / italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-approximate equilibrium of a Leontief economy with 2‚Å¢n2ùëõ2n2 italic_n goods and 2‚Å¢n2ùëõ2n2 italic_n traders. This polynomial relationship between approximate Nash equilibria of bimatrix games and approximate Walrasian equilibria of Leontief economies is significant because it enables us to apply the recent result of Chen, Deng, and Teng [4] to show that finding an approximate market equilibrium with only O‚Å¢(log‚Å°n)ùëÇùëõO(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n )-bits of precision is as hard as finding an exact market equilibrium, which in turn is as hard as finding a Nash equilibrium of a two-person game or a discrete Brouwer fixed point in the most general settings.

We also consider the smoothed complexity of the Leontief market exchange problem. In the smoothed model introduced by Spielman and Teng [24], an algorithm receives and solves a perturbed instances. The smoothed complexity of an algorithm is the maximum over its inputs of the expected running time of the algorithm under slight random perturbations of that input. The smoothed complexity is then measured as a function of both the input length and the magnitude œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ of the perturbations. An algorithm has smoothed polynomial-time complexity if its smoothed measure is polynomial in nùëõnitalic_n, the problem size, and in 1/œÉ1ùúé1/\sigma1 / italic_œÉ [24, 25].

The smoothed complexity of the Leontief exchange problem (ùêÑ¬Ø,ùêÉ¬Ø)¬ØùêÑ¬ØùêÉ(\bar{\mathbf{E}},\bar{\mathbf{D}})( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_E end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG bold_D end_ARG ) is then measured by the expected complexity of finding an equilibrium of the Leontief economy (ùêÑ,ùêÉ)ùêÑùêÉ(\mathbf{E},\mathbf{D})( bold_E , bold_D ).

The following has been an open question in the smoothed analysis of algorithms.

Question 3 (Smoothed Polynomial Leontief?).

Can an equilibrium of a Leontief economy be computed in smoothed time polynomial in mùëömitalic_m, nùëõnitalic_n, and 1/œÉ1ùúé1/\sigma1 / italic_œÉ?

Can an œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ-equilibrium of a Leontief economy be computed in smoothed time polynomial in mùëömitalic_m, nùëõnitalic_n, 1/œµ1italic-œµ1/\epsilon1 / italic_œµ and 1/œÉ1ùúé1/\sigma1 / italic_œÉ?

A concrete open question has been whether the smoothed complexity of the classic Scarf‚Äôs general fixed-point approximation algorithm [22] is polynomial for solving the Leontief market exchange problem.

By refining our analysis of the reduction from the two-person games to Leontief economies, we show it is unlikely that Scarf‚Äôs algorithm has polynomial smoothed complexity for computing an approximate equilibrium of Leontief economies. In particular, we prove that, unless PPAD ‚äÜ\subseteq‚äÜ RP, the problem of finding an (approximate) equilibrium of a Leontief economy is not in smoothed polynomial time.

3 Approximate Nash Equilibria of Two-Person Games

The non-zero-sum two-person game or the bimatrix game is a non-cooperative game between two players [18, 15, 16], the row player and the column player. If the row player has mùëömitalic_m pure strategies and the column player has nùëõnitalic_n pure strategies, then their payoffs are given by a pair of m√ónùëöùëõm\times nitalic_m √ó italic_n matrices (ùêÄ,ùêÅ)ùêÄùêÅ(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B})( bold_A , bold_B ).

The expected payoffs to these two players are respectively ùê±‚ä§‚Å¢ùêÄùê≤superscriptùê±topùêÄùê≤\mathbf{x}^{\top}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{y}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Ay and ùê±‚ä§‚Å¢ùêÅùê≤superscriptùê±topùêÅùê≤\mathbf{x}^{\top}\mathbf{B}\mathbf{y}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_By. Every two-person game has at least one Nash equilibrium [18]. But in a recent breakthrough, Chen and Deng [3] proved that the problem of computing a Nash equilibrium of a two-person game is PPAD-complete.

One can relax the condition of Nash equilibria and considers approximate Nash equilibria. There are two possible notions of approximation.

Definition 3.1 (Approximate Nash equilibria).

An œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ-approximate Nash equilibrium of game (ùêÄ,ùêÅ)ùêÄùêÅ(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B})( bold_A , bold_B ) is a pair of mixed strategies (ùê±*,ùê≤*)superscriptùê±superscriptùê≤(\mathbf{x}^{*},\mathbf{y}^{*})( bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), such that for all ùê±,ùê≤‚àà‚Ñônùê±ùê≤superscript‚Ñôùëõ\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}\in\mathbb{P}^{n}bold_x , bold_y ‚àà blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

Definition 3.2 (Relatively Approximate Nash equilibria).

Note that the Nash equilibria and the relatively-approximate Nash equilibria of a two-person game (ùêÄ,ùêÅ)ùêÄùêÅ(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B})( bold_A , bold_B ) are invariant under positive scalings, i.e., the bimatrix game (c1‚Å¢ùêÄ,c2‚Å¢ùêÅ)subscriptùëê1ùêÄsubscriptùëê2ùêÅ(c_{1}\mathbf{A},c_{2}\mathbf{B})( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_A , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_B ) has the same set of Nash equilibria and relatively-approximate Nash equilibria as the bimatrix game (ùêÄ,ùêÅ)ùêÄùêÅ(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B})( bold_A , bold_B ), as long as c1,c2>0subscriptùëê1subscriptùëê20c_{1},c_{2}>0italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0. On the other hand, Nash equilibria and approximate Nash equilibria are invariant under shifting, that is, for any constants c1subscriptùëê1c_{1}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and c2subscriptùëê2c_{2}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the bimatrix game (c1+ùêÄ,c2+ùêÅ)subscriptùëê1ùêÄsubscriptùëê2ùêÅ(c_{1}+\mathbf{A},c_{2}+\mathbf{B})( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_A , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_B ) has the same set of Nash equilibria and approximate Nash equilibria as the bimatrix game (ùêÄ,ùêÅ)ùêÄùêÅ(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B})( bold_A , bold_B ). However, shifting may not preserve the relatively-approximate Nash equilibria.

Thus, we often normalize the matrices ùêÄùêÄ\mathbf{A}bold_A and ùêÅùêÅ\mathbf{B}bold_B so that all their entries are between 0 and 1, or between -1 and 1, in order to study the complexity of approximate Nash equilibria [17, 4].

Recently, Chen, Deng, and Teng [4] proved the following result.

Theorem 3.3 (Chen-Deng-Teng).

The problem of computing an 1/n61superscriptùëõ61/n^{6}1 / italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-approximate Nash equilibrium of a normalized n√ónùëõùëõn\times nitalic_n √ó italic_n two-person game is PPAD-complete.

As pointed out in [4], the 6 in the exponent of the above theorem can be replaced by any positive constant. One can easily derive the following corollary.

Corollary 3.4 (Relative approximation is also hard).

It remains PPAD-complete to compute a 1/nŒò‚Å¢(1)1superscriptùëõnormal-Œò11/n^{\Theta(1)}1 / italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œò ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-relatively-approximate Nash equilibrium of an n√ónùëõùëõn\times nitalic_n √ó italic_n two-person game.

4 Leontief Market Equilibria: Approximation and Smoothed Complexity

In this and the next sections, we analyze a reduction œÄùúã\piitalic_œÄ that transforms a two-person game (ùêÄ¬Ø,ùêÅ¬Ø)¬ØùêÄ¬ØùêÅ(\bar{\mathbf{A}},\bar{\mathbf{B}})( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_A end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG bold_B end_ARG ) into a Leontief economy (ùêÑ¬Ø,ùêÉ¬Ø)=œÄ‚Å¢(ùêÄ¬Ø,ùêÅ¬Ø)¬ØùêÑ¬ØùêÉùúã¬ØùêÄ¬ØùêÅ(\bar{\mathbf{E}},\bar{\mathbf{D}})=\pi(\bar{\mathbf{A}},\bar{\mathbf{B}})( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_E end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG bold_D end_ARG ) = italic_œÄ ( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_A end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG bold_B end_ARG ) such that from each (œµ/n)2superscriptitalic-œµùëõ2(\epsilon/n)^{2}( italic_œµ / italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-approximate Walrasian equilibrium of (ùêÑ¬Ø,ùêÉ¬Ø)¬ØùêÑ¬ØùêÉ(\bar{\mathbf{E}},\bar{\mathbf{D}})( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_E end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG bold_D end_ARG ) we can construct an œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ-relatively-approximate Nash equilibrium of (ùêÄ¬Ø,ùêÅ¬Ø)¬ØùêÄ¬ØùêÅ(\bar{\mathbf{A}},\bar{\mathbf{B}})( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_A end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG bold_B end_ARG ).

We will also consider the smoothed complexity of Leontief economies. To establish a hardness result for computing an (approximate) market equilibrium in the smoothed model, we will examine the relationship of Walrasian equilibria of a perturbed instance (ùêÑ,ùêÉ)ùêÑùêÉ(\mathbf{E},\mathbf{D})( bold_E , bold_D ) of (ùêÑ¬Ø,ùêÉ¬Ø)¬ØùêÑ¬ØùêÉ(\bar{\mathbf{E}},\bar{\mathbf{D}})( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_E end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG bold_D end_ARG ) and approximate Nash equilibria of (ùêÄ¬Ø,ùêÅ¬Ø)¬ØùêÄ¬ØùêÅ(\bar{\mathbf{A}},\bar{\mathbf{B}})( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_A end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG bold_B end_ARG ). In particular, we show that if the magnitude of the perturbation is œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ, then we can construct an (œµ+n1.5‚Å¢œÉ)italic-œµsuperscriptùëõ1.5ùúé(\epsilon+n^{1.5}\sqrt{\sigma})( italic_œµ + italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1.5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG )-relatively-approximate Nash equilibrium of (ùêÄ¬Ø,ùêÅ¬Ø)¬ØùêÄ¬ØùêÅ(\bar{\mathbf{A}},\bar{\mathbf{B}})( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_A end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG bold_B end_ARG ) from each (œµ/n)2superscriptitalic-œµùëõ2(\epsilon/n)^{2}( italic_œµ / italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-approximate equilibria of (ùêÑ,ùêÉ)ùêÑùêÉ(\mathbf{E},\mathbf{D})( bold_E , bold_D ).

Because the analysis needed for approximate Walrasian equilibria is a special case (with œÉ=0ùúé0\sigma=0italic_œÉ = 0) of the analysis for the smoothed model, we will write only one proof for this general case, and present it in the next section.

In this section, we discuss the reduction from two-person games to Leontief economies, connect the smoothed model with approximation, and present the main theorems of this paper.

4.2 Reduction from NASH to LEONTIEF

Codenotti et al [5] prove that there is a one-to-one correspondence between Nash equilibria of the two person game (ùêÄ,ùêÅ)ùêÄùêÅ(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B})( bold_A , bold_B ) and market equilibria of Leontief economy (ùêÑ¬Ø,ùêÉ¬Ø)¬ØùêÑ¬ØùêÉ(\bar{\mathbf{E}},\bar{\mathbf{D}})( over¬Ø start_ARG bold_E end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG bold_D end_ARG ). We will prove the following extension of their result in the next section.

Lemma 4.1 (Approximation of Games and Markets).

6 Remarks and Open Questions

In this section, we briefly summarize some remarkable algorithmic accomplishments in the computation of (approximate) market equilibria obtained prior to this work. We then present some open questions motivated by these and our new results.

6.1 General Market Exchange Problems and Algorithmic Results

In our paper, we have focused on Leontief market exchange economies. Various other market economies have been considered in the literature [23, 9].

An instance of a general market exchange economy with nùëõnitalic_n traders and mùëömitalic_m goods is given by the endowment matrix ùêÑùêÑ\mathbf{E}bold_E together with nùëõnitalic_n utilities functions v1,‚Ä¶,vnsubscriptùë£1‚Ä¶subscriptùë£ùëõv_{1},\dots,v_{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then an equilibrium price vector is a vector ùê©ùê©\mathbf{p}bold_p satisfying

‚àÉùêó‚àà‚Ñùm√ón,ùêó‚Å¢ùüè‚Üí‚â§ùêÑ‚Å¢ùüè‚Üí,ùêó‚ä§‚Å¢ùê©‚â§ùêÑ‚ä§‚Å¢ùê©,¬†and¬†‚Å¢uj‚Å¢(ùê±j)=max‚Å°{uj‚Å¢(ùê±j‚Ä≤):‚ü®ùê±j‚Ä≤|ùê©‚ü©‚â§‚ü®ùêûj|ùê©‚ü©}.formulae-sequenceùêósuperscript‚Ñùùëöùëõformulae-sequenceùêó‚Üí1ùêÑ‚Üí1formulae-sequencesuperscriptùêótopùê©superscriptùêÑtopùê©¬†and¬†subscriptùë¢ùëósubscriptùê±ùëó:subscriptùë¢ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùê±ùëó‚Ä≤inner-productsuperscriptsubscriptùê±ùëó‚Ä≤ùê©inner-productsubscriptùêûùëóùê©\exists\ \mathbf{X}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n},\mathbf{X}\vec{\mathbf{1}}\leq\mathbf{E}\vec{\mathbf{1}},\ \mathbf{X}^{\top}\mathbf{p}\leq\mathbf{E}^{\top}\mathbf{p},\ \mbox{ and }u_{j}(\mathbf{x}_{j})=\max\left\{{u_{j}(\mathbf{x}_{j}^{\prime}):\left\langle\mathbf{x}_{j}^{\prime}|\mathbf{p}\right\rangle\leq\left\langle\mathbf{e}_{j}|\mathbf{p}\right\rangle}\right\}.‚àÉ bold_X ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m √ó italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_X over‚Üí start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG ‚â§ bold_E over‚Üí start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG , bold_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_p ‚â§ bold_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_p , and italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_max { italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) : ‚ü® bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_p ‚ü© ‚â§ ‚ü® bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_p ‚ü© } .

The celebrated theorem of Arrow and Debreu [1] states that if all utility functions are concave, then the exchange economy has an equilibrium. Moreover, if these functions are strictly concave, then for each equilibrium price vector ùê©ùê©\mathbf{p}bold_p, its associated exchange ùêóùêó\mathbf{X}bold_X or utilities is unique.

A popular family of utility functions is the CES (standing for Constant Elasticity of Substitution) utility functions. It is specified by an m√ónùëöùëõm\times nitalic_m √ó italic_n demand matrix ùêÉùêÉ\mathbf{D}bold_D. The utility functions are then defined with the help of an additional parameter œÅ‚àà(‚àí‚àû,1]‚àñ{0}ùúå10\rho\in(-\infty,1]\setminus\left\{{0}\right\}italic_œÅ ‚àà ( - ‚àû , 1 ] ‚àñ { 0 }:

uj(œÅ)‚Å¢(ùê±j)=(‚àëi=1mdi‚Å¢j‚Å¢xi‚Å¢jœÅ)1œÅsubscriptsuperscriptùë¢ùúåùëósubscriptùê±ùëósuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösubscriptùëëùëñùëósuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëóùúå1ùúåu^{(\rho)}_{j}(\mathbf{x}_{j})=\left(\sum\limits_{i=1}^{m}d_{ij}x_{ij}^{\rho}\right)^{\frac{1}{\rho}}italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_œÅ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_œÅ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

As œÅ‚Üí‚àí‚àû‚Üíùúå\rho\rightarrow-\inftyitalic_œÅ ‚Üí - ‚àû, CES utilities become the Leontief utilities. When œÅ=1ùúå1\rho=1italic_œÅ = 1, the utility functions are linear functions.

Remarkablely, an (approximate) equilibrium of an exchange economy with linear utilities functions can be found in polynomial time [20, 12, 27, 13]. In fact, Ye shows that an œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ-equilibrium of such an market with nùëõnitalic_n traders and nùëõnitalic_n goods can be found in O‚Å¢(n4‚Å¢log‚Å°(1/œµ))ùëÇsuperscriptùëõ41italic-œµO(n^{4}\log(1/\epsilon))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 / italic_œµ ) ) time [27]. If data is given as rational numbers of LùêøLitalic_L-bits, then an exact equilibrium can be found in O‚Å¢(n4‚Å¢L)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõ4ùêøO(n^{4}L)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L ) time.

A closely related market exchange model is the Fisher‚Äôs model [23]. In this model, there are two types of traders: producers and consumers. Each consumer comes to the market with a budget and a utility function. Each producer comes to the market with an endowment of goods and will sell them to the consumers for money. An equilibrium is a price vector ùê©ùê©\mathbf{p}bold_p for goods so that if each consumer spends all her budget to maximize her utilities, then the market clears, i.e., at the end of the exchange, all producers sold out.

Even more remarkablely, an (approximate) equilibrium in a Fisher‚Äôs economy with any CES utilities can be found in polynomial time [11, 27, 28, 10, 14].

6.2 Open Questions

Our results as well as the combination of Codenotti, Saberi, Varadarajan, and Ye [5] and Chen and Deng [3] demonstrate that exchange economies with Leontief utility functions are fundamentally different from economies with linear utility functions. In Leontief economies, not only finding an exact equilibrium is likely hard, but finding an approximate equilibrium is just as hard.

Although, we prove that the computation of an O‚Å¢(1/nŒò‚Å¢(1))ùëÇ1superscriptùëõŒò1O(1/n^{\Theta(1)})italic_O ( 1 / italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œò ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )-approximate equilibrium of Leontief economies is PPAD-hard. our hardness result does not cover the case when œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ is a constant between 00 and 1111. 7 Acknowledgments

We, especially the second author, would like to thank Xi Chen and Xiaotie Deng for their invaluable impact to this paper. It was their remarkable breakthrough result that 2-NASH is PPAD-complete and their joint work with the second author on the complexity of approximate equilibria of 2-NASH that made this paper possible.
